issues.description: The solution introduces a `LectureName` class and changes the type of the `lectureName` attribute from `String` (as specified in the UML and implied by the template) to `LectureName`. This diverges from the problem statement, which clearly uses `String` for `lectureName`, and leaves students unable to follow the specification without creating an unmentioned helper class.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a `String` type for the `lectureName` attribute in the solution (remove or repurpose the `LectureName` class), matching the UML and the template instructions.

issues.description: The solutionâ€™s constructor signature takes a `LectureName` object as its first parameter, but the problem statement and UML expect a `String lectureName`. This mismatch will prevent students from implementing the constructor as specified.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the constructor in the solution to accept a `String lectureName` (in the same order) instead of a `LectureName` object to align with the specification and template.

issues.description: The `lectureName` attribute is specified as type `String` in the UML diagram and expected in the template, but the solution introduces a new `LectureName` class for this attribute. This difference in identifier (and type) for the same conceptual entity (`lectureName`) can confuse students mapping the problem requirements to the solution code.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a consistent type for `lectureName` across artifacts. Either revert the solution to use `String lectureName` (removing the `LectureName` class) or update the template and UML to use `LectureName` as the attribute type.
